text: Hey! No worries at all, I hope it's a good kind of busy! It was amazing, my first time outside of Europe, we went over to Boston via New York, to see some ice hockey! :smile: Ah cool! I've met a few people from that school it seems great, have you been 100% focused on compositing, or only since joining your masters? They started joining the role together just before I joined a few years ago (I think I may have been on the first project with it joint) - it made sense on TV productions with tight turnarounds that the post artist has control over both light and comp scenes, and makes fixes much more fluid! A fair amount of us have generalist backgrounds so were already pretty happy to do both, have noticed roles popping up in a few other places with them joint as well.

hello! the school is great and gives you the opportunity to experiment a lot, personally when I came here I already new that comp was the way but I did some CG for the first module and then again lighting more recently so do what it takes to finish the project (even if the less CG I have to do them the better it is). Currently I'm doing a bit of grading as well as I enjoy pipeline and workflow quite a lot and in the school is up to the colourists, so I joined their ranks to be able to influence that a bit more and that plus the 5 graduation projects I'm working on is keeping me quite busy (so good busy). I've head that Pixar now is making the lighting guys comp as well so I guess that it's  kind of a trend and it looks that the departments boundaries are fading with time... Now "awkward" question for you, have you ever mentored before or are we both freshmen in this? I need to admit that I have no clue of what should happen or how to behave in this...
